name: William Whitaker & Sons, Inc.
biography:
William Whitaker & Sons is one of the oldest Philadelphia textile mills. It was established in 1813 by Henry Whitaker. He had first opened a firm in Rochdale, England, in 1796. He then visited the United States in 1807, which encourage him to relocated his business in Hudson, N.Y. in 1809. He eventually built a waterwheel textile factory in Cedar Grove along Tacony Creek, in the Philadelphia area. Henry Whitaker eventually resigned in 1822 and gave the company to his two sons Robert and William.
The company’s records showed sixty-eight workers in 1840. 
William Whitaker & Sons, Inc. continued operations for 157 years in the original buildings. The business remained in the Whitaker family for six generations. It was incorporated as William Whitaker & Sons, Inc. on September 30, 1946.
Canvas and wool blankets were produced during the Civil War as military supplies until World War II. It was the first mill in the U.S.A to make mattress ticking. The manufacture also produced heavy cotton cloths. William Whitaker & Sons, Inc. emphasized on mechanical-engineering skills developments in the machinery. Robert Chase Whitaker designed a chenille yarn-producing machine, and this manufacturing process was patented. The Whitaker firm sold directly to retailers, particularly to the retail store, Boyd, White & Co.
The owners ceased production in 1970. And the mill was demolished in 1975. Several original buildings remain nearby.
